Two years ago, Chancellor Kohl was the most powerful leader of a resurgent Europe and acted as if he knew it. Today, a year and a half after German unification, he seems much less self-assured, his authority at home and abroad shaken by political and social turmoil. 1

As the Russian capital celebrated its first officially nonpolitical May Day in three-quarters of a century, tens of thousands of Communists gathered in Red Square to denounce the Russian Government and its supporters in the West. 2 CHINA EXPELS LABOR ADVOCATES

Seven Europeans, including legislators from Britain, Germany and Switzerland, were detained and then expelled for going to Tiananmen Square and unfurling banners calling for free labor unions. 4 THE PRESIDENT PREACHES

The head of Afghanistan's interim Government preached in Kabul's largest mosque, calling for unity and an end to the fighting that ravaged the country. He promised an Islamic government and free elections. 3 BOSNIA'S MUSLIMS LOOK TO WEST

Driven from their homes by Serbian guerrillas, Bosnia's Muslim Slavs, one of the world's most secular Islamic communities, are looking toward the West rather than Arab nations for help. 3 LET'S TALK, U.S. SAYS TO PERU

The first high-level talks between the Bush Administration and President Fujimori since the Peruvian leader suspended democratic institutions will be held today in Lima. 4 A PROPOSAL ON GLOBAL WARMING

The chairman of a United Nations negotiating committee offered a plan that officials from several countries said could provide the basis for an agreement to curb emission of some gases. 3 National 5-11 A STAGGERING TOWARD PEACE

Although shootings and knifings continued sporadically, the looting and fires that had marked two days of nearly unchecked rioting in Los Angeles tapered off sharply. But the death toll had soared to 38, more than the number killed in the Watts riots a generation ago, and violence flared in several other cities around the country. 1 In South-Central Los Angeles, anger and a sense of futility. 7 In the Los Angeles County morgue, 38 victims of urban upheaval. 7 Rodney King called for an end to the violence. 6 South Korea asked for protection of Korean-Americans. 9 TV Critic's Notebook: Of one videotape, and then many more. 7 RESPONSE BY THE WHITE HOUSE

On a day of urgent meetings and rapid decisions, President Bush sent 1,000 Federal law-enforcement officers to Los Angeles and ordered 4,000 soldiers to a staging area there. The President said he had been stunned by the verdicts in the Rodney King beating case, and his Attorney General announced that a Federal grand jury was already reviewing evidence to determine whether Mr. King's civil rights had been violated. 1 Excerpts from Bush's address to the nation. 8 The forces sent by Bush are trained for the role. 8 News analysis: The riots' implications for this election year. 9 Clinton is now searching for the right tone on the race issue. 9 A NEWLY EMBATTLED POLICE CHIEF

Now in his final weeks of leading the Los Angeles police force, Daryl F. Gates has been confronted by the most severe crisis of his 14-year tenure as Chief. Some supporters say he has handled the rioting well. But critics -- and there are many -- say his vaunted abilities failed him at a crucial moment. 1 RUMORS OF MELEE ROIL NEW YORK

Panicked by the stark television images of rioting in Los Angeles, New York acted like a city under siege. Well before scattered violence broke out, shopkeepers pulled down their metal shutters and jumpy commuters created an early rush hour, racing home before nightfall. 1 CHEATING ON EXAM DAY

Most of the 350,000 high school students who are taking their college entrance examination today will rely on hard work, concentration and a bit of luck. But a few are likely to try cheating, and two recent cases illustrate how difficult it will be to catch them without infringing on the rights of other students. 1 CHALLENGE TO HOUSE BANK INQUIRY
